Topic.Title: What is so hard to understand that the 1% paying 40% of all taxes now, and only 20% in 1980

Message.Msg: Actually your comments stand as non sequiters. The SIMPLE truth is that the total taxes paid by the top has doubled, and the number of people that make up the top has more than doubled. The major diff from 1980 to now is the lack of ANY total fed income taxes paid by the bottom 49%. As far as unearned income, you are fooling yourself if you refer to the hedge fund practice of carried interest as it is not that big and, hopefully, will be changed. If you refer to normal dividends, interest, and cap gains, then younger a simpleton. Capital is needed to carry capitalism, and punishing said ALREADY TAXED monies again at higher rates is idiotic. Also, for a nation with a dismal savings rate (thus helping drive the fear of politicians to effect any changes to entitlements such as social security as we don't save enough for retirement), adding more disincentive to save would pile on the level of idiocy. As for cap gains, Pres. Clinton had a very strong understanding of exactly what cap gains are and how decreasing taxes on them drove MORE revenues to the treasury. This is evidenced by A) his decision to cut cap gain rates, and B) the resulting windfall to the treasury. I would like to say I am shocked by your lack of understanding of both history and tax-and-effect scenarios, but I am not given your I intellectual dwarf status!

Message.Msg: Capital is needed to carry capitalism Because salaried work is not needed to carry capitalism? Therefore can be taxed more? Let's say we raise tax on dividends and capital gains, then what are people with savings going to do? Keep it in cash? Because they prefer not earn anything than give slightly more of it to the government? What you are saying is plain absurd. As far as saving rates, this is a nation that is bent on discouraging saving. Every policy is twisted to discourage saving, and particularly the monetary policy. If you wanted to encourage saving you could easily without giving special rights to people who earn money this way rather than that way. And the truth is what they really encourage is speculation, not investments. That's why we had a housing bubble. Americans are very good at speculating and very bad at working for a honest salary.

Topic.Title: What is so hard to understand that the 1% paying 40% of all taxes now, and only 20% in 1980

Message.Msg: and punishing said ALREADY TAXED monies again Money is taxed when received on salaries, it is taxed when spent (sales tax), it is taxed again when given by the company as salary (payroll tax). Money is taxed again and again. It's a fact of life. But I don't see any republican out there claiming that salaries are double taxed. Why not? People have low wages which translate in low consumer demand, which what the economy is suffering from. Companies on the other hand have record profits. The economy is not suffering from companies profits being taxed too much. If taxes are needed, the gov needs take the money where it is.

Message.Title: A good take on why we must not use a European economic model.
Message.Msg: A great quote from Lee Kuan Yew's new book of his writings and speeches: "Americans and European governments believed that they could always afford to support the poor and the needy: widows, orphans, the old and homeless, disadvantaged minorities, unwed mothers. Their sociologists expounded the theory that hardship and failure were due . . . to flaws in the economic system. So charity became 'entitlement,' and the stigma of living on charity disappeared." Welfare costs grew faster than the government's willingness to raise taxes. They "took the easy way out by borrowing to give higher benefits to the current generation of voters." The result: deficits and dangerously high public debt.

Topic.Title: Half of all debt belongs to Democrats, and growing daily!

Message.Msg: Debt grew 9% a year on average since Reagan. It doubled every 8 years. This has nothing to do to dems or reps. It's called keynesianism. The belief that sending your technologies, capital and jobs to poor countries will somehow benefit you coupled with the belief that borrowing money is the same as earning it, as long as you spend it. Unsurprisingly the result is catastrophic.

Topic.Title: What is so hard to understand that the 1% paying 40% of all taxes now, and only 20% in 1980

Message.Msg: Let me give you a bit of knowledge: If I lend $1 at 5% for a year, at the end of this year I will get $1.05. If I then lend this for 1 more year, I will get $1.1025. If I lend all the money accumulated for n years, I will get (1.05)^n This means as long as you keeping reinvesting the proceeds in stocks, bonds, RE, etc... rather than spending it, any idiot can grow his/her money exponentially. And the exponential grows faster the underlying economy. This in turns means that, with enough time, these people growing their fortunes that way will always suck every penny out of the productive economy. That much is a mathematical fact. It becomes a problem every 70 years or so in capitalism. When you get there, you see massive inequalities between the rent takers and, on the other side people/companies/governments with huge debts. Historically there were only 2 solutions: the socialist one, called redistribution (tax the rich), and the capitalist one, called depression: let the financial system go kaboom and purge the rot out of the system.

Message.Msg: Don't confuse debt with balance sheet shenanigans.

Topic.Title: What is so hard to understand that the 1% paying 40% of all taxes now, and only 20% in 1980

Message.Msg: Duh! As Einstein intimated, compound interest is the most powerful force in the universe. Your example lacks realistic merit as that is how reinvested stock dividends currently work, yet ZOWIE! Not everyone has a fortune, and every penny has not been sucked out of the economy. One reason, among many, is that your poor example assumes people would be happy with, in your example, a 5% return. If anything is clear in this world, it is that investors will almost always flock to a little more risk (sometimes a lot) to chase returns better than the next guy and better than basic interest. There will always be the dream of getting rich, quick, via equities. The result, a simp,e fact of history, is that most will end up on the garbage heap of failed investors, Your dismal tale is neither cautionary nor apocalyptic, just dismal and droll (and more than a tad condescending).
